caption: Tatyana Petrovna found three bodies on Monday in Bucha, Ukraine, where evidence grew that Russians had killed scores of civilians.
image_1.context: There have been other atrocities in the weeks since Russia invaded Ukraine, concentrating much of its firepower on the dwellings and gathering spots of ordinary Ukrainians, but the international outrage they provoked has been eclipsed by the reaction to revelations that retreating Russian soldiers left many slain civilians Perhaps it was the way the lifeless bodies, bloodied by bullets, and some with hands bound, had been left strewn about or shoveled into makeshift mass graves. Or the reality of seeing them up close in widely circulated photographs and videos. By RICK GLADSTONE Dead for Days In the Streets, Hands Bound  VOL. CLXXI . . . No. 59,384 © 2022 The New York Times Company NEW YORK, TUESDAY, APRIL 5, 2022 HORROR GROWS OVER SLAUGHTER IN UKRAINE
image_1.description: The image depicts a somber and distressing scene in what appears to be a backyard or garden area. A woman, dressed in a blue jacket and floral pants, stands with her hand on her face, seemingly distraught. She is standing near three bodies lying on the ground. The bodies are positioned in various postures: one is partially covered by a blanket, another is lying face down, and the third is lying on its back. The setting is outdoors, with bare trees and some greenery visible. There are scattered objects around, including a yellow box and some debris. The overall atmosphere is one of tragedy and despair, reflecting the aftermath of a violent event.

caption: The aftermath of a Russian strike on a cultural center serving as a barracks in Kharkiv, Ukraine.
image_2.context: The images of dead Ukrainians, some with their hands tied and others haphazardly buried in pits, spurred shocked Western leaders on Monday to promise even tougher sanctions against Russia, including possibly on energy, as the Kremlin dug in and showed signs of preparing a new assault. The growing evidence that Russian soldiers killed scores of civilians in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, leaving their bodies behind as they withdrew, prompted President Biden to call for President Vladimir V. Putin to face a “war crime trial.” By ANTON TROIANOVSKI and MATINA STEVIS-GRIDNEFF Rising Evidence Pushes Europe to Consider Harsh Energy Sanctions 25 days He looked exhausted, his face waxy and pale. He said he had been put through what he called a mock execution 15 times while being questioned about local Ukrainian territorial defense forces and ammunition stored in the area. His interrogators fired an assault rifle over his head during the questioning, he said. His eyes were bound with sticky tape, but he heard and felt the gunshot above his head. “It was psychological pressure,” he said. “They were trying to kick out of me information that I was not sharing.” Two other men also described Continued on Page A9
image_2.description: The image depicts the aftermath of a Russian strike on a cultural center serving as a barracks in Kharkiv, Ukraine. The scene is characterized by extensive damage to a multi-story building with broken windows and exposed interiors. The ground is churned up and muddy, suggesting recent heavy activity or shelling. Two individuals, likely soldiers, are seen walking through the debris field. They are dressed in military gear, including helmets and backpacks, indicating their readiness for combat or patrol. The overall atmosphere is one of desolation and destruction, with no signs of active life other than the two soldiers. The background shows more buildings, some of which also appear damaged, contributing to the sense of widespread devastation. The trees in the area are bare, adding to the bleakness of the scene.

caption: Delivering aid to civilians in Nova Basan, Ukraine.
image_3.context: While Russian troops have battered Ukraine, officials in China have been meeting behind closed doors to study a Communist Party-produced documentary that extols President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a hero. The humiliating collapse of the Soviet Union, the video says, was the result of efforts by the United States to destroy its legitimacy. With swelling music and sunny scenes of present-day Moscow, the documentary praises Mr. Putin for restoring Stalin’s standing as a great wartime leader and for renewing patriotic pride in Russia’s past. To the By CHRIS BUCKLEY Beijing Campaign Casts Russia As the West’s Longtime Victim  resilience after the initial shock of the wideranging Western sanctions put in place after Mr. Putin’s invasion in February, the Kremlin appeared to be girding for a continuation of the war, despite talk in European capitals of now possibly banning Russian coal, oil or, less likely, gas. “They are not going to stop,” Oleksiy Danilov, the secretary of the National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine, said in a statement on Monday. “Putin’s order given to his soldiers to destroy our state has not disappeared.” In a visit to Bucha on Monday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Continued on Page A9
image_3.description: The image depicts a scene of humanitarian aid delivery in Nova Basan, Ukraine. In the foreground, a woman wearing a headscarf and a dark coat is holding two red and white striped bags, possibly containing food or supplies. She appears to be receiving these items from a person whose arm is visible on the left side of the image, suggesting they are handing out aid. Behind her, another woman with a scarf around her neck is standing near a green wooden fence, observing the situation. To the right, a soldier in camouflage gear stands guard, adding a sense of security to the scene. The background shows a rural setting with leafless trees and a house, indicating a cold season. The overall atmosphere conveys a sense of resilience and community support amidst challenging circumstances.

image_4.context: The country’s ruling family is facing its toughest challenge yet as protesters demand that the president step down amid economic turmoil. PAGE A8 Activist Avoids Life Sentence The man who inspired “Hotel Rwanda” had been given a 25-year term in a case condemned by rights Uproar in Sri Lanka INTERNATIONAL A4-13  Jury Picks Begin in Sentencing Jurors will decide if the gunman in the Parkland shooting should be sentenced to death or life in prison. PAGE A19 Senate Deal Cuts Covid Funds Negotiators announced a \$10 billion package that scraps spending for the global vaccine effort. PAGE A16 NATIONAL A14-19 to Curbing Warming mental Panel on Climate Change, a body of experts convened by the United Nations, warns that unless countries drastically accelerate efforts over the next few years to slash their emissions from coal, oil and natural gas, the goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, or 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit, will likely be out of reach  That’s the threshold beyond which scientists say the dangers of global warming — including worsening floods, droughts, wildfires and ecosystem collapse — grow considerably. Humans have already heated the planet by an average of 1.1 degrees Celsius Continued on Page A6
image_4.description: The image shows a chain-link fence with multiple red heart-shaped decorations attached to it. The hearts are evenly spaced and connected by thin red strings, creating a pattern across the fence. The background features a grassy hill with some scattered trees and bushes, suggesting an outdoor setting. The sky is partly cloudy, adding to the natural ambiance of the scene. The overall atmosphere conveyed by the image is one of love or remembrance, as the hearts symbolize affection and the setting provides a serene backdrop.

image_5.context: The Generational Grammys Despite nods to Gen Z, this year’s awards show seemed to favor historyminded performers like Silk Sonic, Jon Batiste, H.E.R. and Lady Gaga, Jon Caramanica writes. PAGE C1 Bigotry in Extra Innings A revival of “Take Me Out,” Richard Greenberg’s play ARTS C1-8  Jayhawks Are Back on Top No. 1 Kansas rallied to top North Carolina, an eighth seed, to capture its first men’s N.C.A.A. title since 2008. PAGE B6 A Manager’s Joy? It’s the Shoes. Terry Francona, largely out for two seasons with health issues, is back and feisty with the Guardians. image_5.description: The image captures a moment from a basketball game, likely during the NCAA tournament given the context provided. Two players are in the foreground, one with his back to the camera and the other facing forward. The player facing forward has curly hair and is wearing a white jersey with blue and red accents, which appears to be the uniform of the Kansas Jayhawks, as indicated by the context. He is embracing the other player, who is also in a similar uniform, suggesting a celebratory or supportive gesture. The background shows a crowded arena with spectators, indicating a high-stakes game. The atmosphere conveyed is one of excitement and triumph, possibly after a significant play or at the end of the game. The lighting is bright, typical of indoor sports arenas, and the focus is on the emotional interaction between the two players.

image_6.context: SCIENCE TIMES D1-8 Eight Arms, but Not Nine Lives Octopuses are hard to use for research because they escape from aquariums and die shortly after laying eggs. image_6.description: The image shows a close-up of a person's hands holding a small, striped lizard. The lizard has a distinctive black and yellow striped pattern on its body and legs. It is perched on what appears to be a light-colored, textured surface, possibly a piece of wood or a rock. The hands are gently cradling the lizard, with fingers positioned to support it from underneath. The background is dark, which contrasts with the bright colors of the lizard and the light surface it is on. The overall atmosphere of the image conveys a sense of care and fascination with the creature.
